utterances: No, not really.
Made me feel little.
Made you feel what?
Little.
Made you feel little?
Well, we are getting some anecdotal accounts of such incidents.
And they are being dealt with by the police and other relevant authorities where they are.
But I think the key thing to remember is that Britain is a diverse society.
And we are hugely welcoming.
And these incidents are rare, but when they do occur, you know, we must deal with them very, very firmly.
You announced that you are going to back your brother's bid for leadership of the Conservative Party, which is your party as well.
Many hope that this will lead to him becoming prime minister.
Was it a hard decision to decide that you would back him, given you were on different sides, as you say?
No.

I mean, I've no doubt at all that he's the person best-placed, not just to secure a new settlement for Britain in Europe, but also to provide the optimistic, confident and outward-looking leadership that we're going to need more than ever now in months and years to come.
I want to ask you one question about his leadership specifically.

I mean, he had a bus, and there was a pledge emblazoned on it during this campaign, promising that these 350 million British pounds that go each week to the European Union would be spent on the National Health Service in the U.K.
if the vote went in the right way.
Nigel Farage, who, you know, was the architect of the Leave campaign, said very quickly that it was a mistake to promise that.
Is there a credibility problem here?
Boris doesn't have a credibility problem whatsoever.
He's got a towering record as mayor of London.
And he's demonstrated, in that role, you know, that he can lead one of the world's great urban civilizations successfully.
He set a big, bold vision for our capital city.
He was hugely successful in that role in attracting unprecedented growth and levels of inward investment into the city.
He renewed the transport system.
He took crime down to record lows.
So he's got a substantial body of achievement in government, which I think he can be hugely proud of and which is a great track record for him as he seeks to be prime minister of this country.
Jo Johnson is a member of the British Parliament and serves as the minister of state for universities and science.
Thanks so much for coming on the program.
We appreciate it.
Thank you.
If you've flown in or out of Chicago's O'Hare Airport in the last 16 years, there's a chance Willie Ashford(ph) handled your luggage.

He's the lead ramp serviceman for United Airlines and he's among the more than 120,000 workers and retirees who stand to be affected by Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation's takeover of United's pension plan.
United estimates that this change will reduce the pension benefits for ramp workers like Mr. Ashford by about half.
Pay cuts over the last three years have already reduced his salary from $25 an hour to about 19.
Mr. Ashford is 50 years old and he and his wife have two teen-age children.
He joins us from member station WBEZ in Chicago.
Mr.
Ashford, thanks for being with us.
Thank you very much.
Yeah.
Thank you for having me here.
Now what was your reaction when you heard that United was ending its pension plan?
When I first heard it, I was at first confused; didn't quite understand, you know, what it all meant until, you know, I did a little research.
It's kind of depressing now.
Yeah.
What did you find?
I mean, what have you heard about how this is going to affect your finances?
Well, I found that all of my pension that's accumulated over time until I'm ready to retire has stopped.
That means that all of the accumulation of my pension--you know, it appears that I'm going to have to work a little bit longer now.
Yeah.
How much have you planned for your retirement?
In terms of dollars, you know, I've got the 401(k) and some other investments that I have, but I was also depending on that pension.
That's...
Do you have any other sources of income?
You know, I do, you know, a little painting, a little T-shirt business that I do on the side.
So you have all these little things...
Little things.
...and your salary and that's essentially it.
Does your wife work?
Yeah, she does, but still, you know, we're struggling--well, just making it right now, but, you know, if something happens to her, if something happens to me, it's a strain on one of us, you see?
You have kids.
I mean, your kids are teen-agers.
They're looking at college pretty soon.
Yeah, I've got one kid that in about two years he's maybe going to college.
You know, at this point, I'm not sure.
We have to figure some things out and make some adjustments, see if we're still going in that direction.
So it might be a junior college.
I don't know about a four-year college at this point.
So your salary's being cut.
Your pension...
...being cut.
What's the mood like at work?
They're depressed.
You know, they're concerned.
You know, how would you feel, you know, if you loved your job and you worked hard to get what you've got and then all of a sudden it's taken away from you little by little?
It's depressing.
Those guys, including myself--we love the job.
We do the job.
We try to do our best.
You know, the customer right now is our priority.
So we continue on until the union can work out something with the company.
Willie Ashford is the lead ramp serviceman for United Airlines in Chicago.
He joined us from the studios of WBEZ.
Thanks a lot.
Thank you.
Oh, Scout...
Yeah.
We know that the protocol says that it's only the president who can issue these orders.
Some people say it is not the president but the minister.
And now, they're pushing it further down by basically saying it is the deputy minister who is the head of the security forces, who actually issued the order without the minister knowing.
So that's basically the question: Where does the buck stop?
The testimony was frustrating to protesters who were attacked, like Sarah Abdel-Rahman.
It's basically the biggest case in Egypt's history and, you know, everyone is very careful about what they're saying.
She says Egyptians need Mubarak to be held accountable.
Even if he didn't know that Ahmed Ramzy ordered people to have live ammunition, then this in itself is a problem.
Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson, NPR News, Cairo.
You know, if you remember anything from today's program, I hope it's this.
When Somali pirates were holding a U.S.
ship captain hostage last week, Kathy Urbik of Wheaton, Illinois grew worried.

On Sunday, news came that Captain Richard Phillips had been rescued, but that still didn't ease her mind because her son, Tom, a 26-year-old marine engineer was on the Liberty Sun, which is another U.S.
ship in the waters off Somalia.

I was getting very nervous for Tom because I hadn't heard from him in a while and I was hearing the reports on the news that the Somali pirates had vowed revenge and were going to try to attack American ships and not take prisoner, just kill them.
Then yesterday morning she got an email titled, I love you all.
It was from her son Tom and it wasn't exactly reassuring because it also saidâ€¦
We are under attack by pirates.
We are being hit by rockets, also bullets.
We are barricaded in the engine room and so far no one is hurt.
It seemed that her worst fears were being realized.

That was pretty alarming and very scary, but I only had to deal with that for a minute or two because the email that came in almost immediately after I read that one was the one that said the Navy had arrived, they were safe, and they were escorted into Mombasa.
That escort was the USS Bainbridge, the same U.S.
Navy ship that rescued Captain Richard Phillips on Sunday.
Ms. Urbik says she knows what she'd like to hear next from her son.
